t: Amos 1
The*p words of Amos, one of the shepherds of Tekoa—the vision he saw concerning Israel two years before the earthquake, when Uzziah was king of Judah and Jeroboam son of Jehoash was king of Israel.
He*p said: “The*pn Lord*s roars from Zion and*ld thunders from Jerusalem; the*ln pastures of the shepherds dry up, and*ld the top of Carmel withers.”
Judgment on Israel’s Neighbors
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Damascus, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln she threshed Gilead with*ld sledges having iron teeth,
I*ln will send fire on the house of Hazael that*ld will consume the fortresses of Ben-Hadad.

I*ln will break down the gate of Damascus; I*ld will destroy the king who is in the Valley of Aven and*ln the one who holds the scepter in Beth Eden. The*ld people of Aram will go into exile to Kir,” says*ld the Lord.*s
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Gaza, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln she took captive whole communities and*ld sold them to Edom,
I*ln will send fire on the walls of Gaza that*ld will consume her fortresses.

I*ln will destroy the king of Ashdod and*ld the one who holds the scepter in Ashkelon. I*ln will turn my hand against Ekron, till*ld the last of the Philistines are dead,” says*ld the Sovereign Lord.*s
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Tyre, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln she sold whole communities of captives to Edom, disregarding*ld a treaty of brotherhood,
I*ln will send fire on the walls of Tyre that*ld will consume her fortresses.”

This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Edom, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln he pursued his brother with a sword and*ld slaughtered the women of the land, because*ln his anger raged continually and*ld his fury flamed unchecked,
I*ln will send fire on Teman that*ld will consume the fortresses of Bozrah.”
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Ammon, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln he ripped open the pregnant women of Gilead in*ld order to extend his borders,
I*ln will set fire to the walls of Rabbah that*ld will consume her fortresses amid*ln war cries on the day of battle, amid*ld violent winds on a stormy day.
Her*ln king will go into exile, he*ld and his officials together,” says*ld the Lord.*s
Amos 2
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Moab, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln he burned to ashes the*ld bones of Edom’s king,
I*ln will send fire on Moab that*ld will consume the fortresses of Kerioth. Moab*ln will go down in great tumult amid*ld war cries and the blast of the trumpet.
I*ln will destroy her ruler and*ld kill all her officials with him,” says*ld the Lord.*s

This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Judah, even*ld for four, I will not relent. Because*ln they have rejected the law of the Lord*s and*ld have not kept his decrees, because*ln they have been led astray by false gods, the*ld gods their ancestors followed,
I*ln will send fire on Judah that*ld will consume the fortresses of Jerusalem.”
Judgment on Israel
This*p is what the Lord*s says: “For*pn three sins of Israel, even*ld for four, I will not relent. They*ln sell the innocent for silver, and*ld the needy for a pair of sandals.
They*ln trample on the heads of the poor as*ld on the dust of the ground and*ld deny justice to the oppressed. Father*ln and son use the same girl and*ld so profane my holy name.
They*ln lie down beside every altar on*ld garments taken in pledge. In*ln the house of their god they*ld drink wine taken as fines.
“Yet*pn I destroyed the Amorites before them, though*ld they were tall as the cedars and*ld strong as the oaks. I*ln destroyed their fruit above and*ld their roots below.
I*ln brought you up out of Egypt and*ld led you forty years in the wilderness to*ld give you the land of the Amorites.
“I*pn also raised up prophets from among your children and*ld Nazirites from among your youths. Is*ln this not true, people of Israel?” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“But*pn you made the Nazirites drink wine and*ld commanded the prophets not to prophesy.
“Now*pn then, I will crush you as*ld a cart crushes when loaded with grain.
The*ln swift will not escape, the*ld strong will not muster their strength, and*ld the warrior will not save his life.
The*ln archer will not stand his ground, the*ld fleet-footed soldier will not get away, and*ld the horseman will not save his life.
Even*ln the bravest warriors will*ld flee naked on that day,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
Amos 3
Witnesses Summoned Against Israel
Hear*p this word, people of Israel, the word the Lord*s has spoken against you—against the whole family I brought up out of Egypt:
“You*pn only have I chosen of*ld all the families of the earth; therefore*ln I will punish you for*ld all your sins.”
Do*pn two walk together unless*ld they have agreed to do so?
Does*ln a lion roar in the thicket when*ld it has no prey? Does*ln it growl in its den when*ld it has caught nothing?
Does*ln a bird swoop down to a trap on the ground when*ld no bait is there? Does*ln a trap spring up from the ground if*ld it has not caught anything?
When*ln a trumpet sounds in a city, do*ld not the people tremble? When*ln disaster comes to a city, has*ld not the Lord*s caused it?
Surely*pn the Sovereign Lord*s does nothing without*ld revealing his plan to*ld his servants the prophets.
The*pn lion has roared— who*ld will not fear? The*ln Sovereign Lord*s has spoken— who*ld can but prophesy?

Proclaim*pn to the fortresses of Ashdod and*ld to the fortresses of Egypt: “Assemble*ln yourselves on the mountains of Samaria; see*ld the great unrest within her and*ld the oppression among her people.”
“They*pn do not know how to do right,” declares the Lord,*s “who*ld store up in their fortresses what*ld they have plundered and looted.”
Therefore*p this is what the Sovereign Lord*s says: “An*pn enemy will overrun your land, pull*ld down your strongholds and*ld plunder your fortresses.”

This*p is what the Lord*s says: “As*pn a shepherd rescues from the lion’s mouth only*ld two leg bones or a piece of an ear, so*ln will the Israelites living in Samaria be rescued, with*ld only the head of a bed and*ld a piece of fabric from a couch.”
“Hear*p this and testify against the descendants of Jacob,” declares the Lord, the Lord*s God Almighty.
“On*pn the day I punish Israel for her sins, I*ld will destroy the altars of Bethel; the*ln horns of the altar will be cut off and*ld fall to the ground.
I*ln will tear down the winter house along*ld with the summer house; the*ln houses adorned with ivory will be destroyed and*ld the mansions will be demolished,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
Amos 4
Israel Has Not Returned to God
Hear*pn this word, you cows of Bashan on Mount Samaria, you*ld women who oppress the poor and crush the needy and*ld say to your husbands, “Bring us some drinks!”
The*ln Sovereign Lord*s has sworn by his holiness: “The*ld time will surely come when*ln you will be taken away with hooks, the*ld last of you with fishhooks.
You*ln will each go straight out through*ld breaches in the wall, and*ld you will be cast out toward Harmon,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“Go*pn to Bethel and sin; go*ld to Gilgal and sin yet more. Bring*ln your sacrifices every morning, your*ld tithes every three years.
Burn*ln leavened bread as a thank offering and*ld brag about your freewill offerings— boast*ln about them, you Israelites, for*ld this is what you love to do,” declares*ld the Sovereign Lord.*s
“I*pn gave you empty stomachs in every city and*ld lack of bread in every town, yet*ld you have not returned to me,” declares*ld the Lord.*s

“I*pn also withheld rain from you when*ld the harvest was still three months away. I*ln sent rain on one town, but*ld withheld it from another. One*ln field had rain; another*ld had none and dried up.
People*ln staggered from town to town for water but*ld did not get enough to drink, yet*ld you have not returned to me,” declares*ld the Lord.*s

“Many*pn times I struck your gardens and vineyards, destroying*ld them with blight and mildew. Locusts*ln devoured your fig and olive trees, yet*ld you have not returned to me,” declares*ld the Lord.*s

“I*pn sent plagues among you as*ld I did to Egypt. I*ln killed your young men with the sword, along*ld with your captured horses. I*ln filled your nostrils with the stench of your camps, yet*ld you have not returned to me,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“I*pn overthrew some of you as*ld I overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah. You*ln were like a burning stick snatched from the fire, yet*ld you have not returned to me,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“Therefore*pn this is what I will do to you, Israel, and*ld because I will do this to you, Israel, prepare*ld to meet your God.”

He*pn who forms the mountains, who*ld creates the wind, and*ld who reveals his thoughts to mankind, who*ln turns dawn to darkness, and*ld treads on the heights of the earth— the*ld Lord*s God Almighty is his name.
Amos 5
A Lament and Call to Repentance
Hear*p this word, Israel, this lament I take up concerning you:
“Fallen*pn is Virgin Israel, never*ld to rise again, deserted*ln in her own land, with*ld no one to lift her up.”

This*p is what the Sovereign Lord*s says to Israel: “Your*pn city that marches out a thousand strong will*ld have only a hundred left; your*ln town that marches out a hundred strong will*ld have only ten left.”
This*p is what the Lord*s says to Israel: “Seek*pn me and live;
do*ld not seek Bethel, do*ln not go to Gilgal, do*ld not journey to Beersheba. For*ln Gilgal will surely go into exile, and*ld Bethel will be reduced to nothing.”
Seek*ln the Lord*s and live, or*ld he will sweep through the tribes of Joseph like a fire; it*ln will devour them, and*ld Bethel will have no one to quench it.
There*pn are those who turn justice into bitterness and*ld cast righteousness to the ground.

He*pn who made the Pleiades and Orion, who*ld turns midnight into dawn and*ld darkens day into night, who*ln calls for the waters of the sea and*ld pours them out over the face of the land— the*ld Lord*s is his name.
With*ln a blinding flash he destroys the stronghold and*ld brings the fortified city to ruin.
There*pn are those who hate the one who upholds justice in court and*ld detest the one who tells the truth.

You*pn levy a straw tax on the poor and*ld impose a tax on their grain. Therefore,*ln though you have built stone mansions, you*ld will not live in them; though*ln you have planted lush vineyards, you*ld will not drink their wine.
For*ln I know how many are your offenses and*ld how great your sins. There*pn are those who oppress the innocent and take bribes and*ld deprive the poor of justice in the courts.
Therefore*ln the prudent keep quiet in such times, for*ld the times are evil.
Seek*pn good, not evil, that*ld you may live. Then*ln the Lord*s God Almighty will be with you, just*ld as you say he is.
Hate*ln evil, love good; maintain*ld justice in the courts. Perhaps*ln the Lord*s God Almighty will have mercy on*ld the remnant of Joseph.

Therefore*p this is what the Lord, the Lord*s God Almighty, says: “There*pn will be wailing in all the streets and*ld cries of anguish in every public square. The*ln farmers will be summoned to weep and*ld the mourners to wail.
There*ln will be wailing in all the vineyards, for*ld I will pass through your midst,” says*ld the Lord.*s
The Day of the Lord
Woe*pn to you who long for*ld the day of the Lord!*s Why*ln do you long for the day of the Lord?*s That*ld day will be darkness, not light.
It*ln will be as though a man fled from a lion only*ld to meet a bear, as*ln though he entered his house and*ld rested his hand on the wall only*ld to have a snake bite him.
Will*ln not the day of the Lord*s be darkness, not light— pitch-dark,*ld without a ray of brightness?
“I*pn hate, I despise your religious festivals; your*ld assemblies are a stench to me.
Even*ln though you bring me burnt offerings and grain offerings, I*ld will not accept them. Though*ln you bring choice fellowship offerings, I*ld will have no regard for them.
Away*ln with the noise of your songs! I*ld will not listen to the music of your harps.
But*ln let justice roll on like a river, righteousness*ld like a never-failing stream!
“Did*pn you bring me sacrifices and offerings forty*ld years in the wilderness, people of Israel?
You*ln have lifted up the shrine of your king, the*ld pedestal of your idols, the*ld star of your god— which*ld you made for yourselves.
Therefore*ln I will send you into exile beyond Damascus,” says*ld the Lord,*s whose name is God Almighty.
Amos 6
Woe to the Complacent
Woe*pn to you who are complacent in Zion, and*ld to you who feel secure on Mount Samaria, you*ln notable men of the foremost nation, to*ld whom the people of Israel come!
Go*ln to Kalneh and look at it; go*ld from there to great Hamath, and*ld then go down to Gath in Philistia. Are*ln they better off than your two kingdoms? Is*ld their land larger than yours?
You*ln put off the day of disaster and*ld bring near a reign of terror.
You*ln lie on beds adorned with ivory and*ld lounge on your couches. You*ln dine on choice lambs and*ld fattened calves.
You*ln strum away on your harps like David and*ld improvise on musical instruments.
You*ln drink wine by the bowlful and*ld use the finest lotions, but*ld you do not grieve over the ruin of Joseph.
Therefore*ln you will be among the first to go into exile; your*ld feasting and lounging will end.
The Lord Abhors the Pride of Israel
The*p Sovereign Lord*s has sworn by himself—the Lord*s God Almighty declares: “I*pn abhor the pride of Jacob and*ld detest his fortresses; I*ln will deliver up the city and*ld everything in it.”
If*p ten people are left in one house, they too will die.

And if the relative who comes to carry the bodies out of the house to burn them asks anyone who might be hiding there, “Is anyone else with you?” and he says, “No,” then he will go on to say, “Hush! We must not mention the name of the Lord.”*s
For*pn the Lord*s has given the command, and*ld he will smash the great house into pieces and*ld the small house into bits.
Do*pn horses run on the rocky crags? Does*ld one plow the sea with oxen? But*ln you have turned justice into poison and*ld the fruit of righteousness into bitterness—
you*ln who rejoice in the conquest of Lo Debar and*ld say, “Did we not take Karnaim by our own strength?”
For*pn the Lord*s God Almighty declares, “I*ld will stir up a nation against you, Israel, that*ln will oppress you all the way from*ld Lebo Hamath to the valley of the Arabah.”
Amos 7
Locusts, Fire and a Plumb Line
This*p is what the Sovereign Lord*s showed me: He was preparing swarms of locusts after the king’s share had been harvested and just as the late crops were coming up.
When they had stripped the land clean, I cried out, “Sovereign Lord,*s forgive! How can Jacob survive? He is so small!”
So*p the Lord*s relented. “This*p will not happen,” the Lord*s said.
This*p is what the Sovereign Lord*s showed me: The Sovereign Lord*s was calling for judgment by fire; it dried up the great deep and devoured the land.
Then I cried out, “Sovereign Lord,*s I beg you, stop! How can Jacob survive? He is so small!”
So*p the Lord*s relented. “This*p will not happen either,” the Sovereign Lord*s said.
This*p is what he showed me: The Lord was standing by a wall that had been built true to plumb, with a plumb line in his hand.
And the Lord*s asked me, “What do you see, Amos?” “A*p plumb line,” I replied. Then*p the Lord said, “Look, I am setting a plumb line among my people Israel; I will spare them no longer.
“The*pn high places of Isaac will be destroyed and*ld the sanctuaries of Israel will be ruined; with*ld my sword I will rise against the house of Jeroboam.”
Amos and Amaziah
Then*p Amaziah the priest of Bethel sent a message to Jeroboam king of Israel: “Amos is raising a conspiracy against you in the very heart of Israel. The land cannot bear all his words.
For this is what Amos is saying: “ ‘Jeroboam*pn will die by the sword, and*ld Israel will surely go into exile, away*ld from their native land.’ ”
Then*p Amaziah said to Amos, “Get out, you seer! Go back to the land of Judah. Earn your bread there and do your prophesying there.
Don’t prophesy anymore at Bethel, because this is the king’s sanctuary and the temple of the kingdom.”
Amos*p answered Amaziah, “I was neither a prophet nor the son of a prophet, but I was a shepherd, and I also took care of sycamore-fig trees.
But the Lord*s took me from tending the flock and said to me, ‘Go, prophesy to my people Israel.’
Now then, hear the word of the Lord.*s You say, “ ‘Do*pn not prophesy against Israel, and*ld stop preaching against the descendants of Isaac.’

“Therefore*p this is what the Lord*s says: “ ‘Your*pn wife will become a prostitute in the city, and*ld your sons and daughters will fall by the sword. Your*ln land will be measured and divided up, and*ld you yourself will die in a pagan country. And*ln Israel will surely go into exile, away*ld from their native land.’ ”
Amos 8
A Basket of Ripe Fruit
This*p is what the Sovereign Lord*s showed me: a basket of ripe fruit.
“What do you see, Amos?” he asked. “A*p basket of ripe fruit,” I answered. Then*p the Lord*s said to me, “The time is ripe for my people Israel; I will spare them no longer.
“In*p that day,” declares the Sovereign Lord,*s “the songs in the temple will turn to wailing. Many, many bodies—flung everywhere! Silence!”
Hear*pn this, you who trample the needy and*ld do away with the poor of the land,

saying,*p “When*pn will the New Moon be over that*ld we may sell grain, and*ln the Sabbath be ended that*ld we may market wheat?”— skimping*ln on the measure, boosting*ld the price and*ld cheating with dishonest scales,
buying*ln the poor with silver and*ld the needy for a pair of sandals, selling*ld even the sweepings with the wheat.
The*p Lord*s has sworn by himself, the Pride of Jacob: “I will never forget anything they have done.
“Will*pn not the land tremble for this, and*ld all who live in it mourn? The*ln whole land will rise like the Nile; it*ld will be stirred up and then sink like*ld the river of Egypt.
“In*p that day,” declares the Sovereign Lord,*s “I*pn will make the sun go down at noon and*ld darken the earth in broad daylight.

I*ln will turn your religious festivals into mourning and*ld all your singing into weeping. I*ln will make all of you wear sackcloth and*ld shave your heads. I*ln will make that time like mourning for an only son and*ld the end of it like a bitter day.

“The*pn days are coming,” declares the Sovereign Lord,*s “when*ld I will send a famine through the land— not*ln a famine of food or a thirst for water, but*ld a famine of hearing the words of the Lord.*s
People*ln will stagger from sea to sea and*ld wander from north to east, searching*ln for the word of the Lord,*s but*ld they will not find it.
“In*p that day “the*pn lovely young women and strong young men will*ld faint because of thirst.
Those*ln who swear by the sin of Samaria— who*ld say, ‘As surely as your god lives, Dan,’ or,*ld ‘As surely as the god of Beersheba lives’— they*ld will fall, never to rise again.”
Amos 9
Israel to Be Destroyed

I*p saw the Lord standing by the altar, and he said: “Strike*pn the tops of the pillars so*ld that the thresholds shake. Bring*ln them down on the heads of all the people; those*ld who are left I will kill with the sword. Not*ln one will get away, none*ld will escape.
Though*ln they dig down to the depths below, from*ld there my hand will take them. Though*ln they climb up to the heavens above, from*ld there I will bring them down.

Though*ln they hide themselves on the top of Carmel, there*ld I will hunt them down and seize them. Though*ln they hide from my eyes at the bottom of the sea, there*ld I will command the serpent to bite them.
Though*ln they are driven into exile by their enemies, there*ld I will command the sword to slay them. “I*pn will keep my eye on them for*ld harm and not for good.”
The*pn Lord, the Lord*s Almighty— he*ln touches the earth and it melts, and*ld all who live in it mourn; the*ln whole land rises like the Nile, then*ld sinks like the river of Egypt;
he*ln builds his lofty palace in the heavens and*ld sets its foundation on the earth; he*ln calls for the waters of the sea and*ld pours them out over the face of the land— the*ld Lord*s is his name.
“Are*pn not you Israelites the*ld same to me as the Cushites?” declares*ld the Lord.*s “Did*pn I not bring Israel up from Egypt, the*ld Philistines from Caphtor and*ld the Arameans from Kir?

“Surely*pn the eyes of the Sovereign Lord*s are*ld on the sinful kingdom. I*ln will destroy it from*ld the face of the earth. Yet*ln I will not totally destroy the*ld descendants of Jacob,” declares*ld the Lord.*s
“For*pn I will give the command, and*ld I will shake the people of Israel among*ld all the nations as*ln grain is shaken in a sieve, and*ld not a pebble will reach the ground.
All*ln the sinners among my people will*ld die by the sword, all*ln those who say, ‘Disaster*ld will not overtake or meet us.’
Israel’s Restoration
“In*p that day “I*pn will restore David’s fallen shelter— I*ld will repair its broken walls and*ld restore its ruins— and*ld will rebuild it as it used to be,
so*ln that they may possess the remnant of Edom and*ld all the nations that bear my name,” declares*ld the Lord,*s who will do these things.

“The*p days are coming,” declares the Lord,*s “when*pn the reaper will be overtaken by the plowman and*ld the planter by the one treading grapes. New*ln wine will drip from the mountains and*ld flow from all the hills,

and*ld I will bring my people Israel back from exile. “They*pn will rebuild the ruined cities and live in them. They*ld will plant vineyards and drink their wine; they*ld will make gardens and eat their fruit.
I*ln will plant Israel in their own land, never*ld again to be uprooted from*ld the land I have given them,” says*pld the Lord*s your God.
